    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
August marks the two-year anniversary of Hurricane
  Katrina but at least 86,000 families are still living in those white FEMA
  trailers along the Gulf
Coast. While FEMA may
  have helped shelter a lot of families, our investigative team has discovered
  that the trailers may be toxic to the people who call them home.
  Investigative Correspondent Armen Keteyian will report.
 
Sharyl Attkisson is also reporting from the Gulf Coast.
  Tonight she’ll have an update on New
    Orleans and the surrounding area – how far has
  it really come since Katrina?
 
In South
    Carolina last night, Republican Presidential
  candidates took the stage for their second debate. As our senior political
  correspondent Jeff Greenfield will report, there were more than a few sparks.
  He’ll have the highlights.
 
In health news, we’ll look into the Internet
  and its growing role as a place to find prescription drugs. But, as Wyatt
  Andrews will report, much of that buying and selling is done illegally
  without prescriptions – so much that it is catching the attention of
  legislators on Capitol Hill.
 
Younger and younger kids are using cell phones
  – and parents are paying the price as kids ring up big bills for games,
  ringtones and other electronic accessories. The catch: kids don’t need
  a parent’s go-ahead before adding charges their bill. Richard
  Schlesinger will have the story as well as some solutions.
 
Finally, we’ve got a story about possible
  Irish roots popping up in an unlikely spot in American politics. According to
  members of one little church on the Emerald Isle, records show a potential
  genealogical connection to the 2008 presidential race. I’ll give you a
  hint – his surname isn’t O’Malley or O’Connor, but it
  does start with an “O.” 
 
I hope you’ll join us,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
